description: From Anglo-Norman proffessur, from Latin professor (“declarer, person who claims knowledge”), from the past participle stem of profiteor (“profess”).

entries.meaning: The most senior rank for an academic at a university or similar institution, informally also known as "full professor."
(US, informal) A teacher or faculty member at a college or university regardless of formal rank.
(archaic) One who professes something, such as a religious doctrine.
examples: This period in which Abraham the Jew lived was one in which Magic was almost universally believed in, and in which its Professors were held in honour;

entries.meaning: (US, slang) A pianist in a saloon, brothel, etc.
examples: You could hear [...] pianos under the hands of whorehouse professors sounding like they came with keys between the keys.

entries.meaning: The puppeteer who performs a Punch and Judy show; a Punchman.
